head.title: To Heal the Poor of the World

hedline.hl1: To Heal the Poor of the World

abstract.p: Letter from Dr Richard J Brown says May 21 article suggests that relieving misery of disease-ridden Africa and other poor regions cannot be entrusted to for-profit drug makers

block.p: As ''Drug Makers and 3rd World: Study in Neglect'' (front page, May 21) suggests, relieving the misery of disease-ridden Africa and other poor regions cannot be entrusted to the for-profit drug makers. When companies abandon unprofitable drugs, when the international president of Doctors Without Borders says that ''he who can't pay, dies'' is the logic of the market, when drug executives agree with that but, as one says, have a ''commitment to deliver performance for shareholders,'' it is time to look elsewhere for solutions.

As ''Drug Makers and 3rd World: Study in Neglect'' (front page, May 21) suggests, relieving the misery of disease-ridden Africa and other poor regions cannot be entrusted to the for-profit drug makers. When companies abandon unprofitable drugs, when the international president of Doctors Without Borders says that ''he who can't pay, dies'' is the logic of the market, when drug executives agree with that but, as one says, have a ''commitment to deliver performance for shareholders,'' it is time to look elsewhere for solutions.

Only adequately financed national and international agencies like the World Health Organization, which eradicated smallpox, are in a position to undertake this work. An international effort to reduce and eliminate diseases: What better way to measure the moral progress of mankind?
RICHARD J. BROWN, M.D. New York, May 22, 2000
